questions.text: Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Boyle’s law states that, at a given temperature, the product of pressure time’s volume for a gas is constant.

PV = nRT

Boyle's law:

  • At a given temperature, the product of pressure times volume for a gas is constant
  • PV=nRT

Charles law:

  • At constant pressure, the volume occupied by a fixed mass of gas is proportional to temperature
  • V/T = constant

Dalton's Law:

  • It states that the partial pressure of a gas in a mixture of gases is the pressure that gas would exert if it occupied the total volume of the mixture.
  • Partial pressure is the total pressure multiplied by the fractional concentration of dry gas.

Henry's Law:

  • The amount of gas dissolved is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas with which it is in equilibrium.

Graham's Law:

  • The rate of diffusion of a gas is inversely proportional to molecular weight.

questions.text: Transport of CO is diffusion limited because_____

choices.text: Alveolar membrane is less permeable to CO
High affinity of CO to hemoglobin

questions.solution:
Transport of CO is diffusion limited because of the high affinity of CO to hemoglobin.

Diffusion across the alveolocapillary membrane:

  • Blood takes 0.75s to traverse pulmonary capillaries.
  • CO diffuses into blood and combines with Hb with very high affinity. Thus the partial pressure of CO doesn't rise (Only dissolved form of gas can increase the partial pressure, Gas which combines with Hb or plasma proteins cannot). Partial pressure gradient necessary for diffusion of CO is maintained for the whole 0.75s and hence it is Diffusion limited.
  • In the case of N2O it does not react and reaches equilibrium in about 0.1s. The amount of N2O taken up is not limited by diffusion but by the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries; that is, it is Flow-limited.
  • O2 is intermediate between N2O and CO; it is taken up by haemoglobin, but much less avidly than CO, and it reaches equilibrium with capillary blood in about 0.3 s. Thus, its uptake is Perfusion-limited.

In the case of perfusion limited gases, an increase in pulmonary blood flow increases the amount of gas transferred. Hence O2 transport increases with an increase in pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: What is the percentage of O2 carried, chemically bound to Hb?
questions.solution:
Percentage of O2 carried chemically (bound to Hb) is 97%.

Oxygen is transported in the blood in two forms:

  • physically 3% - dissolved in plasma 
  • chemically 97% - bound to hemoglobin.

Remember:

Gases are transported in 3 forms:

  • Dissolved gas - This is the form which contributes to partial pressure. Nitrogen is carried only in dissolved form in blood.
  • Bound gas - O2, CO are bound to Hb in RBC; CO2 is bound to Hb in RBC as well as plasma protein.
  • Chemically modified gas - CO2 in the form of HCO3-.

Total gas concentration in solution is the sum of dissolved gas plus bound gas plus chemically modified gas.

questions.text: The presence of hemoglobin in normal arterial blood increases its O2 concentration approximately by how many times?
questions.solution:
The presence of hemoglobin in normal arterial blood increases its O2 concentration approximately by 70 times

  • Normal arterial blood has Po2 of about 100 mm Hg.

Amount of O2 transported in dissolved form (Calculated by using Henry's law):

  • Concentration of dissolved O2 = Partial pressure of O2 × solubility of O2 = 100 mmHg × 0.003 mL O2/100 mL blood per mm Hg = 0.3 mL O2/100 mL
  • Hence 1L of plasma has 3mL of 02 in dissolved form.
  • 5L of plasma can carry maximum 15mL of 02.
  • At rest, O2 demand is around 250mL/min. 
  • Hence dissolved O2 alone is not sufficient to meet body demands.

Amount of O2 transported bound to Hb:

  • Concentration of Hb is 15g/100 mL
  • Each gram of Hb binds to 1.34 mL of O2
  • Hence, 15 g binds to 20.1mL of O2/100 mL
  • On average, the 15 g of hemoglobin in 100 mL of blood can combine with a total of about 20 mL of O2.

Thus, this value (20.1) in the presence of Hb is about 70 times the value (0.3) in the absence of Hb.

questions.text: Each molecule of hemoglobin carries ______ molecules of O2.
questions.solution:
Hemoglobin has 4 subunits each of which has heme molecule and polypeptide chain. Ferrous in heme binds to a molecule of O2. Hence, hemoglobin binds to 4 molecules of O2.

  • Hemoglobin is a protein made up of four subunits.
  • Each subunit contains a heme moiety attached to a polypeptide chain.
  • Heme is a porphyrin ring complex that includes one atom of ferrous iron.
  • In normal adults, most of the hemoglobin molecules contain two α and two β chains.
  • Each of the four iron atoms in hemoglobin can reversibly bind one O2. The iron stays in the ferrous state so that the reaction is oxygenation (not oxidation).

questions.text: Most of the CO2 transported in the arterial blood is in the form of_____
questions.solution:
CO2 is carried in the blood in three forms:

  • Bicarbonate (HCO3−) - Quantitatively the most important(70%)
  • Carbaminohemoglobin (23%)
  • Dissolved CO2 (7%)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hemoglobin is false?

choices.text: The T configuration of Hb does not favor O2 binding
The R configuration of Hb does not favor O2 binding
The R configuration of Hb favors O2 binding
Each Hb molecules carries 4 oxygen molecules

questions.solution:
A relaxed (R) configuration, exposes more O 2 binding sites.

The quaternary structure of hemoglobin determines its affinity for O2.

In deoxyhemoglobin, the globin units are tightly bound in a tense (T) configuration, which reduces the affinity of the molecule for O2.

When O 2 is first bound, the bonds holding the globin units are released, producing a relaxed (R) configuration, which exposes more O2 binding sites. The net result is a 500-fold increase in O2

In tissues, these reactions are reversed, resulting in O2  dissociation .

questions.text: The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoid shape because_____

choices.text: Binding of one O2 molecule increases the affinity of binding of subsequent O2 molecules
Binding of one O2 molecule decreases the affinity of binding of subsequent O2 molecules

questions.solution:
The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoid shape because binding of one O2 molecule increases the affinity of binding of subsequent O2 molecules.

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve relates per­centage saturation of the O2 carrying power of hemoglobin (abbreviated as SaO2) to the Po2. It has a characteristic sigmoid shape due to the T–R interconversion. Combination of the first heme in the Hb molecule with O2 increases the affinity of the second heme for O2 and oxygenation of the second increases the affinity of the third, and so on, such that the affinity of Hb for the fourth O2 molecule is many times that for the first (Positive Co-operative Effect).

Option C: The effect of PCO2 and pH on the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve is called the Bohr effect.

Option D: O2 bound to hemoglobin changes its affinity for CO2, such that when less O2 is bound, the affinity of hemoglobin for CO2 increases. This is referred to as the Haldane effect.

questions.text: Hb would be expected to become 100% saturated with oxygen at Po2 of (in mmHg)_____
questions.solution:
When blood is equilibrated with 100% O2, the normal hemoglobin becomes 100% saturated.

  • In vivo, the hemoglobin in the blood at the end of the pulmonary capillaries is about 97.5% saturated with O2 (Po2 = 100 mm Hg).
  • Because of a slight admixture with venous blood that bypasses the pulmonary capillaries (i.e, physiologic shunt), the hemoglobin in systemic arterial blood is only 97% saturated.
  • Graph relates the percentage of saturated hemoglobin (SaO2) to PO2 and dissolved O2.
Partial pressure of O2 Corresponding SpO2
100 99 - 100%
60 89%
40 75%
27 50%

questions.text: The normal value of P50 in an adult is(mm Hg)______
questions.solution:
Normal P50 is about 27 mm of Hg for adult Hb.

P50 is the partial pressure of O2 at which Hb is 50 % saturated. P50 is an index of the affinity of Hb with O2.

Higher the P50 value, lower is the affinity: Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve shifts to right.

Lower the P50 value, the higher is the affinity: Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve shifts to left.

questions.text: Decrease in pH shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to_____

choices.text: On either side depending on other factors

questions.solution:
The pH decreasing from the normal value shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the right.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

questions.text: Four molecules of myoglobin will bind how many molecules of oxygen?
questions.solution:
4 molecules of myoglobin will bind 4 molecules of oxygen.

  • Myoglobin: This is present in skeletal muscles.
  • 1 molecule of myoglobin binds 1 molecule of O2. Thus, 4 molecules of myoglobin will bind 4 molecules of oxygen
  • The shape of O2-myoglobin dissociation curve is the rectangular hyperbola. It lies to the left of Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve (OHDC)(refer figure).

questions.text: Bohr effect
questions.solution:
Facilitation of oxygen transport depends on the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, explained by the Bohr effect. 

When the metabolic activity of tissues increases, the production of CO2 increases. This CO2 diffuses into the blood and in turn, raises the blood H2CO3 and causes an increase in the H+ concentration and a decrease in pH. This decreases the affinity of Hb for O2, shifting the O2- hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This facilitates the unloading of O2 in the tissues. The effect of Pco2 and pH on O2 hemoglobin dissociation curve is called the Bohr Effect.

Conversely, in the lungs, CO2 diffuses from the blood to the alveoli and the H+ concentration decreases and theO2 hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left increasing the affinity of Hb to O2.

Note: 

Double Bohr effect occurring in the placenta: Oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve of fetal blood and maternal blood move in opposite directions.

Mechanism:

  • The fetal blood entering the placenta carries large amounts of carbon dioxide, but most of it diffuse from the fetal blood into the maternal blood.
  • Fetal blood - loss of CO2 - reduced H+ - shift to left - loading of O2 i.e. oxygenation of fetal Hb.
  • Maternal blood - increase in CO2 - increase in H+ - shift to the right - Release of oxygen.

questions.text: The level of 2,3 –DPG is decreased in______
questions.solution:
The level of 2,3–DPG is decreased in acidosis.

2,3-DPG is produced from 3-phosphoglycerate which is a product of glycolysis. Acidosis inhibits red cell glycolysis which decreases the levels of 2,3-DPG.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

↑ in 2, 3-DPG ↓ in 2, 3-DPG
  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Acclimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: High affinity of HbF to O2 is due to_____
questions.solution:
Increased affinity of HbF to O2 is due to decreased affinity of γ chains of HbF to 2,3DPG.

HbF is the fetal variant of hemoglobin.

The β chains of adult hemoglobin (hemoglobin A) are replaced by γ chains in HbF. This modification results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for O2, a left shift of the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, and decreased P50.
The mechanism of the left shift is based on the binding of 2,3-DPG. 2,3-DPG does not bind as avidly to the γ chains of HbF as it binds to the β chains of hemoglobin A. When less 2,3-DPG is bound, the affinity for O2 increases and facilitates the movement of O2 from the mother to the fetus.

This increased affinity is beneficial to the fetus, whose PaO2 is low (approximately 40 mm Hg).

questions.text: Haldane effect is _______

choices.text: Binding of O2 to Hb favours release of CO2
Binding of CO2 to Hb favours release of O2
HCO3- leaving RBC in exchange for Cl-

questions.solution:
Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect is called the Haldane effect. (Remember - Haldane effect occurs in lungs and causes left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Haldane Effect

  • Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect, called the Haldane effect, is important in promoting CO2 transport.
  • The Haldane effect results from the simple fact that the combination of O2 with hemoglobin in the lungs causes the hemoglobin to become a stronger acid. This displaces CO2 from the blood and into the alveoli.

questions.text: You are comparing the packed cell volume (PCV) obtained from an arterial and venous blood sample of the same patient. Why is PCV higher in venous blood?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit (PCV) of venous blood is normally 3% greater than that of the arterial blood because of 2 reasons:

  • Chloride shift
  • A small amount of fluid in the arterial blood returns via the lymphatics rather than the veins.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.
  • Note that for each CO2 molecule added to a red cell, there is an increase of one osmotically active particles in the cell - either a HCO 3 – or a Cl – ion. Consequently, the red cells take up water and increase in size.

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage:

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

questions.solution:
The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

2, 3 DPG (2,3-diphosphoglycerate) binds to deoxygenated haemoglobin. Therefore, an increase in 2,3 DPG causes increased release of O2 to the tissues. The equilibrium between Hb and O2 can be understood from the following equation:

HbO2 + 2,3-DPG ⇄ Hb−2,3-DPG + O2

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall. As a result, stored blood releases less oxygen to the tissues than the normal circulating blood, thus limiting its use in hypoxic patients (Eg: anaemia).

However, such a fall in 2,3 DPG is less when it is stored in a phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine), rather than ACD (Acid citrate dextrose). Therefore, the blood stored in CPDA, in comparison with blood stored in ACD has:

  • Higher 2,3 DPG concentration
  • More amount of deoxygenated blood bound to 2,3 DPG
  • Decreased affinity of Hb to the oxygen.
  • Increased release of oxygen to the tissues.
  • Raised P50 (PO2 at which Hb is half saturated)
  • Shift in O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right

The Acid citrate dextrose solution was introduced during the second world war, CPD eventually replaced ACD becoming the commonly used preservative. The addition of adenine to CPD improved the ATP synthesis in stored blood, which prolonged the storage of blood cells.

questions.text: The oxygen carrying capacity of a 18 year old boy with haemoglobin of 14g/dl is
questions.solution:
The oxygen carrying capacity of a boy with haemoglobin 14g/dl is 18.

When blood is saturated with 100% O2, the haemoglobin is also 100% saturated and each gram of normal haemoglobin contains 1.39 mL of O2.

However, blood normally contains some inactive haemoglobin derivatives, and the measured value in vivo is thus slightly lower hence, each gram of haemoglobin in vivo contains 1.31 mL of O2 (Hufner’s constant).

According to the above question, when Hb=14g/dl, O2= 1.31*14= 18.34 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve

  • Demonstrates a progressive increase in the percentage of haemoglobin bound with oxygen as blood Po2 increases, which is called the percent saturation of haemoglobin.
  • Blood leaving the lungs and entering the systemic arteries usually has a Po2 of about 95 mm Hg, the usual oxygen saturation of systemic arterial blood averages 97 per cent.
  • Conversely, in normal venous blood returning from the peripheral tissues, the Po2 is about 40 mm Hg, and the saturation of haemoglobin averages 75 per cent.
